issues.title: Next steps

issues.body: @henkbirkholz What are the next steps to progress this? COSE WG mailing list? Any content changes?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: Good for CfA request

issues.title: why not build on countersignatures?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
I think it's be advantageous to frame this as some kind of COSE countersignature.
This way we can reuse all the good work that went in to RFC9338 and build on stacks that already implement it.
In particular, ISTM we can take all of [§3.3](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9338.html#name-signing-and-verification-pr) in terms of defining the target structures, and just specify how `ToBeSigned` is transformed into a RFC3161 `MessageImprint`.

Sketching the produce path:

* populate `Countersign_structure` as specified by RFC9338 except using the string `"RFC3161-TST"` as `context`
* create the value `ToBeSigned` by encoding the `Countersign_structure` to a byte string as per RFC9338
* use `$your_fav_hash_alg` to hash `ToBeSigned` and create an RFC3161 `MessageImprint`
* do the dance with your trusted TSA as specified in RFC3161
* wrap the returned DER encoded `TimeStampToken` in a CBOR byte string and set it as the value of the unprotected header parameter `TBD-RFC3161-TST`

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
visually:

```mermaid
graph TB
  C["COSE thing (payload)"]
  B["RFC9338.Countersign_structure"]
  MI["RFC3161.messageImprint"]
  C --> B
  B -- hash --> MI
  MI -- RFC3161 --> TST
  TST -- unprotected hdr --> C
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This is now OBE as we've chosen to go for a simpler model.

issues.title: a case for the protected header usage
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
As discussed, there may be a use case for "non-countersignature" uses of the header:
```mermaid
graph TB
  C["COSE thing"]
  MI["RFC3161.messageImprint"]
  payload -- hash --> MI 
  MI -- RFC3161 --> TST
  TST -- protected hdr --> C
  payload --> C
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This is now incorporated as Timestamp-Then-COSE (TTC) mode.

issues.title: C2PA use case
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: See C2PA spec, the following two sections specifically: [timestamps](https://c2pa.org/specifications/specifications/2.0/specs/C2PA_Specification.html#_time_stamps) and [validate the timestamps](https://c2pa.org/specifications/specifications/2.0/specs/C2PA_Specification.html#_validate_the_time_stamp).

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: This is now tracked in the wider scope of #17

issues.title: Carl's review
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/QrFj0wP8R0kBjfM3IBITvtC-mSE/

* [ ] In section 3.2, there is language about minimizing dependencies by using the same hash for the timestamp and the signature. This suggestion does not seem to be unique to CTT, so I’d either repeat the language in 3.1 or move the language to a more general location that covers both use cases.

* [ ] In section 4, I suggest changing _“the receiver MUST make sure that the message imprint in the embedded timestamp token matches either the payload or the signature fields, depending on the mode of use”_ to something like _“the receiver MUST make sure that the message imprint in the embedded timestamp token matches a hash of the payload, signature, or signatures field, depending on the mode of use and type of COSE structure”_

issues.title: improve IANA registration requests
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body: [Mike Prorock](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/ODGg2-CgOqGffy0CL_p0kEx4iFA/) and [Michael Jones](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/ol7SeUqighvpJPVYJ90YSC0SM_I/) have pointed out that the current registration requests are rather informal and could be improved using the templates in [S16.2 of RFC8152](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8152#section-16.2).

issues.title: "heavier" security considerations
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
In [his review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/PzdSsG8GP_S2pguJpPOHyIxdHZY/), Orie commented that: _"Security considerations seem light."_

We could add prose that succinctly describes:
1. the attacker model (i.e., a dodgy individual trying to manipulate the COSE signer's or the relying party's local clocks), and
2. the trust model (i.e., local clocks are untrusted, and the TSA clock is trusted by both the COSE signer and its relying parties)

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: The only interesting attack is when the attacker moves the RP's clock in the future.

issues.title: add use cases
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
In [his review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/PzdSsG8GP_S2pguJpPOHyIxdHZY/), Orie commented that: _"Some use cases for the 2 modes might improve the document."_

E.g., C2PA, SCITT, PDF timestamping.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Add a paragraph to the Introduction to explain the use cases.

> _"This specification is motivated by ..."_

issues.title: 9338 reference is confusing
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
In [his review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/PzdSsG8GP_S2pguJpPOHyIxdHZY/), Orie commented that:
> IIRC cose counter signatures apply to the protected header, payload and signature, whereas CTT only applies to the signatures.
>
> This means that the TSA does not countersign any protected information in the header?

The answer is obviously "no", but the fact that the question was raised seems to indicate that the reference to 9338 is potentially confusing.

Note that if we removed it, nothing would change, which is an incentive to drop.

issues.title: allow multiple CTT entries?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
C2PA allows multiple timestamps from different TSAs to be added back into the COSE envelope.

Do we want to do the same and use an array (or the `one-or-more` [construct from RFC9292](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9393.html#section-2-13))?

Note that this may slightly complicate processing (and possibly the trust model too) because there would be many "TSA-time"s that need to be considered rather than just one.

Can that aspect of the processing be punted to "local policy"?  In the end, if an application decides to ask for $n$ TSTs, it does so because it supposedly knows what to do with them.

This probably needs some more discussion.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: **ACTION** @henkbirkholz to ask Leonard on the COSE list.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: **ACTION** completed by @thomas-fossati dearest. C2PA's requirement on multiple TSTs in CTT mode of use is rolled back. If there will be no further responses to the contrary to https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/KfI7Oo7IIFfpK_b6O35sz7G1_8g this issue will be resolved with no changes.

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: resolved

issues.title: A COSE header parameter with two modes or two COSE header parameters for two modes?
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Shuping's email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/wumnJiHpaJpQWkE4GgFNWAVRRbM/):

```
In the Abstract, it says "This document defines a CBOR Signing And Encrypted
(COSE) header parameter for ...". In Section 1, it says "This document defines
two new CBOR Object Signing and Encryption (COSE) [STD96] header parameters
that ..." In Section 3, it says "The two modes described in ... To clearly
separate their semantics two different COSE header parameters are defined as
described in the following subsections."

So is it about two COSE header parameters for two modes? Maybe simply changing
the wording in the Abstract?
```

issues.title: issues with "message imprint" (1)
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Shuping's email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/wumnJiHpaJpQWkE4GgFNWAVRRbM/):

```
2. Section 2.1
To compare through 2.1, 2.2, 3.1, and 3.2, would it be more clear to move this
following sentence to Section 3.1? "The message imprint sent to the TSA
(Section 2.4 of [RFC3161]) MUST be the hash of the payload field of the COSE
signed object."
```

issues.title: issues with "message imprint" (2)
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Shuping's email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/wumnJiHpaJpQWkE4GgFNWAVRRbM/):

```
3. Section 2.1, 3.2
To compare against RFC 3161 and the Figures, should "message imprint" be
"messageImprint"? s/message imprint/messageImprint
```

issues.title: Better alignment between §3.1 with §3.2
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
From [Shuping's email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/wumnJiHpaJpQWkE4GgFNWAVRRbM/):

```
4. Section 3.1
This following sentence could be moved to the end of this sub-section, to
better align with the similar information in Section 3.2. "The 3161-ttc
protected header parameter contains a DER-encoded RFC3161 TimeStampToken
wrapped in a CBOR byte string (Major type 2)."
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Note: Moving the equivalent line in §3.2 is probably better, flow-wise.

6. IANA Considerations
In Table 1.

issues.title: Add examples
issues.author: thomas-fossati
issues.body:
[Linda Dunbar's review](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/cose/J9o7A-DXfeRi72h7EOjL13OE3_I/)


> _"The document provides basic diagrams to illustrate the modes but lacks comprehensive examples of the header parameters in action. It would be nicer to add complete example encodings of COSE messages with the proposed parameter."_

The only problem is that a realistic example can only be crafted once the codepoints are allocated.

Could pick two from "private use" for now and refresh when IANA gives us the real ones.

pulls.title: Review on draft-birkholz-cose-tsa-tst-header-parameter.md
pulls.author: mprorock
pulls.body: Very minor feedback for language clarity

comments.body:
this is not the gist of Carl's comment.  He wants us to factor out this paragraph instead, which is not CTT-specific:

    In either case, to minimize dependencies, the hash algorithm SHOULD
    be the same as the algorithm used for signing the COSE message.  This
    may not be possible if the timestamp token has been obtained outside
    the processing context in which the COSE object is assembled.

```suggestion
| `31610-tcc` | TBD1 | bstr | - | RFC 3161 timestamp token | {{&SELF}}, {{sec-tst-hdr-ttc}} |
| `31610-ctt` | TBD2 | bstr | - | RFC 3161 timestamp token | {{&SELF}}, {{sec-tst-hdr-ctt}} |
```

```suggestion
| `3161-tcc` | TBD1 | bstr | - | RFC 3161 timestamp token | {{&SELF}}, {{sec-tst-hdr-ttc}} |
| `3161-ctt` | TBD2 | bstr | - | RFC 3161 timestamp token | {{&SELF}}, {{sec-tst-hdr-ctt}} |
```

```suggestion
| `31610-tcc` | 31610 | bstr | - | RFC 3161 timestamp token | {{&SELF}}, {{sec-tst-hdr-ttc}} |
| `31610-ctt` | 31611 | bstr | - | RFC 3161 timestamp token | {{&SELF}}, {{sec-tst-hdr-ctt}} |
```

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
> What about "caching" a TST before TTC or CTT?

In CTT that can't happen unless you can predict the COSE signature, i.e., the content of the datum.

> The TST basically tells at minimum "statement not younger than time in TST". By retrieving a TST and then using it later, you can shift that point "more into the past". That is probably is a threat, too?

Sorry, I don't understand this.  You are making a similar point in #25 which I am also failing to grok.  To me, a timestamp asserts the existence of a datum _at least_ at the point in time when the timestamp for that datum is created.  I cannot fathom an attack in which pushing the existence of the datum back in time is an attack on the intended use of the datum.

```suggestion
We assume an attacker who has the ability to manipulate the clocks on the COSE signer and its relying parties, but not the clock of the TSA.
```

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: What about "caching" a TST before TTC or CTT? The TST basically tells at minimum "statement not younger than time in TST". By retrieving a TST and then using it later, you can shift that point "more into the past". That is probably is a threat, too?

comments.body:
```suggestion
Attackers could gain the ability to manipulate the local clocks used by the COSE signer or its relying parties, but not the ability to manipulate the clock of the TSA.
```

```suggestion
Additionally, the TSA is assumed to be a trusted third party, meaning that an attacker cannot impersonate the TSA so that the TSA can only create valid timestamp tokens.
```
the spirit of this suggestion has been captured in [e75174a](https://github.com/ietf-scitt/draft-birkholz-cose-tsa-tst-header-parameter/pull/24/commits/e75174a9281914f13bbd31b6287ad4e029991169)
ditto

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
However, in both CTT and TTC mode, a denial of service can occur if the attacker can adjust the relying party's clock to a past time.
```

```suggestion
However, in both CTT and TTC mode, a denial of service can occur if the attacker can adjust the relying party's clock to a future time.
```

```suggestion
However, in both CTT and TTC mode, a denial of service can occur if the attacker can adjust the relying party's clock so that the CMS validation fails.
```

```suggestion
To avoid that, the signed COSE object should be integrity protected during transit and at rest.
```
I'd split this into two and add the respective bits to the last line of the use case sections.
Suggest adding a NL here, they are two separate paragraphs.
`ETITLETOOLONG` :-D
_"quality"_ doesn't sound like the right word

I find this a bit hard to digest.

You want to prove that _"a certain document existed at a certain date"_ in a way that can't be disputed by a relying party.
ditto

```suggestion
To motivate the two different modes of use that are specified in this documents, two usage scenarios are illustrated in {{use-one}} and {{use-two}} below.

```
Sarcasm aside, I will propose text.
:heart:

```suggestion
In support of legal assurances, a signed PDF document can be augmented with a trustworthy timestamp.
```

```suggestion
In essence, a document signer wants to strengthen the assertion that a certain document existed at a certain date.
```

```suggestion
Using only its local clock instead, a document signer would be able to tamper with its clock and thereby falsify the recentness of the signing procedure.
```

```suggestion
In support of legal assurances, a signed document can be augmented with a trustworthy timestamp.
```

```suggestion
This usage scenario motivates the "COSE then Timestamp" mode below.
```

```suggestion
Once a document is registered at a Transparency Service's append-only log, its log entry cannot be changed.
```

removing the (redundant) bit that is already explained in L76

```suggestion
In certain cases, the registration policy of a Transparency Service may add a trustworthy timestamp to the signed document.
```

```suggestion
This is done to lock the signature to a specific point in time.
```

```suggestion
To achieve this, the Transparency Service acquires a TST from a TSA, bundles it alongside the signed document, and then registers it.
```

```suggestion
A relying party that wants to ascertain the authenticity of the document after the signing key has been compromised, can do so by making sure that no revocation information has been made public before the time asserted in the TST.
```

pulls.title: Move detailed diagrams up a level
pulls.author: thomas-fossati

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: @henkbirkholz @OR13 please have a look

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Good start!

Immediate comments:

1. `imprint` must be `messageImprint` (from RFC3161)
2. Adding "Clock" is like dissecting a frog, innit? :-) (we can add a legenda as in #30)
3. The Signer box in the TTC diagram is a bit too crowded and hard to grasp
4. the fact that `private-key` is repeated is confusing
5. I am not yet sure if I like the stray `unprotected` box, but I could be convinced otherwise

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body: Also, maybe rename them to `alt-{ttc,cct}.ascii-art` and tweak the include directive.

comments.author: thomas-fossati
comments.body:
Thanks @OR13 - I have pulled your nice diagrams into #30

This PR is closed as a consequence of the above.

```suggestion
> RFCed Note: The following example uses the currently unassigned 50 as TBD2.  This example must be regenerated once IANA has allocated the codepoint.
```
:-( sad face emoji
if IANA agrees on 50/51 for TBD2/TBD1 we might get away without having to recompute the examples...
